This is a somewhat curtailed account. I knew this was going to be some task when I picked this up, but as String Theory seems to be hacking at the forefront I thought I'd give it a go. Prof. Brian Greene is someone who has dedicated their whole career to String Theory - so he should know what he's talking about; also he might perhaps be a little biased towards String Theory's acceptance. In order to get where he wants to be Prof. Greene has to do a lot of groundwork and he's good at this. There is a very good explication of General and Special Relativity, the positing of which changed everything. The difficulties start to occur when he begins to try to explain Quantum mechanics in layman’s terms. That’s when it all starts to go pear-shaped. So we start from basics. Electromagnetic waves, photons, quanta. Light can be a particle or a wave, just as an electron can; and an electron can be in any place at any time – or rather its position is based on probability. The electron can travel, in fact DOES travel by every available trajectory but we can either know its position or its velocity, never both. All outcomes are possible with probabilities attached to their occurring. Quantum mechanical solutions have been considered for all the non-gravitational forces. At high enough temperatures(energies) there are close alignments between pairs of forces and this has given rise to the Standard Model of Particle Physics (which is in a sense the opposing camp to the String Theorists). The similarities between two forces at a quantum mechanical level gives rise to ‘symmetries’ which are instructive. Gravity resists being analysed at a quantum mechanical level giving rise to infinities and ‘quantum foam’ at a microscopic level. Thus there is a total mismatch between the smoothness of space-time in the absence of mass and the chaotic nature of space-time at the quantum level. Attempts to resolve these theoretically give rise to infinities which are irresolvable. However the chaotic incompatibility only happens at the ultra small level – 10 to the-33 cm – the Planck length. Some physicists thus discount this whilst others searching for the essential beauty of an all-in-one theory labour on.And so onto String Theory itself. Instead of thinking of fundamental particles and forces as non-dimensional points, they are considered as one-dimensional strings. The maths behind this allowed fundamental particles and nuclear interactions to be modelled, and furthermore appeared to include the properties of the as-yet unobserved graviton, thus including gravity. The problem became that the equations to describe the solutions became approximate with the solutions also being approximate because of the complexity of the equations. The drawback to the Standard Model is that it offers no reason why the values for mass, charge and energy are what they are. String Theory does offer reasons. Individual strings and loops vibrate at resonant frequencies – particular frequencies. Different vibrational patterns give rise to different masses and thus energies. So, according to String Theorists, what is needed is a paradigm shift. What in fact appear to be different fundamental particles are in fact different resonances. Some of the problems are solved by the wondrous world of quantum mechanics, quantum jitter allowing cancellation of too high energies but what also comes out is that some of the properties essential to make String Theory a legitimate description of the universe have so far not been found to exist. So far there is no proof of supersymmetry and superpartners. For its acolytes, String Theory unites gravity with the other forces and allows a unity with quantum mechanics by interpreting all fundamental particles not as non-dimensional points but as having a dimensionality. Furthermore particle interactions are better described from a general relativity viewpoint as strings rather than point particles.  The incompatibility of general relativity and quantum mechanics which would be apparent only on the sub-Planck length distances is avoided in a universe that has a lower limit on the distances that can be accessed or even said to exist in a conventional sense. Thus String Theory is useful. But it throws up another immediate question. We CHOOSE the qualities of the universe we inhabit and make sense of and also CHOOSE to ignore other qualities. Therefore are we not simply accessing a model which we have already pre-determined and defined? This is a philosophic question on the nature of enquiry. From a String Theorist’s point of view, point particles appear to be idealisations; from a classical point particle physicists' view, we have no proof of existence of strings and it is impossible to prove strings (of one-dimensionality) over particles (of zero dimensionality). EXCEPT that the theory associated with strings gives rise to some very elegant solutions to problems within the Standard Model.But the theory itself has some big whoppers to get over. It starts to become really obtuse when Supersymmetry is thrown in, partly because it is never really explained what supersymmetry is. It appears to have to do with partnering of fundamental particles and forces with a difference of Spin ½ – partnering matter particles with Spin ½ with Messenger (Force) particles of Spin 1. Supersymmetry is a really desirable feature (but as yet unproven) as it seriously simplifies the calculations. And there is more than one type of supersymmetry! Furthermore the partnering has to occur with forces of Spin ½ LESS. These (the so called SUPERPARTNERS theoretical have a high mass and are currently not known to exist (this was written before the LHC at CERN started up, and since then the superpartners have not been discovered)). Therefore the cause of Supersymmetry looks slim. We cannot prove experimentally that the superpartners exist... or perhaps Supersymmetry does not exist! This might mean that there is no Grand Unified Theory! For Superstring Theory to accomplish anything it needs the incorporation of multi-dimensionality. To be precise – it needs a 9 dimensional space (or possibly 10). We are familiar with the 3 dimensions of space which have EXTENT. It is posited that the other 6 dimensions (or 7) are curled up and occur at sub-microscopic level i.e. we cannot see them and these 6 / 7 extra dimensions are beyond the level of detection. If we cannot see or detect them can they be said to exist? In order for this to BE then the theory needs to predict outcomes that are provable by experimentation, and this, so far, it has singularly failed to do. So we have String Theory resting on multi-dimensionality of which there is zero proof, and also on supersymmetry, which posits the existence of superpartners which have not (and probably cannot) be discovered. Superstring Theory looks to be pretty ropey! This looked the case by the mid 80’s that the Nobel Laureate Sheldon Glashon said, In lieu of the traditional confrontation between theory and experiment, superstring theorists pursue an inner harmony where elegance, uniqueness and beauty define truth. The theory depends for its existence on magical coincidences, miraculous cancellations and relations between seemingly unrelated (and possibly undiscovered) fields of mathematics. Are these properties reason to accept the reality of superstrings? Do mathematics and aesthetics supplant and transcend mere experiment? Things have moved on from the mid-80s - but have got no simpler. These extra dimensions curled up into a shape (known as a Calabi-Yau shape) - it turns out that not all of them work. So there has been a move towards the intense study of the topology of these shapes to get the theory to work. Even Prof. Greene is given to say .... if none of the Calabi-Yau shapes came even remotely close to yielding observed physical properties, it would seem that String Theory, although a beautiful and elegant framework, could have no relevance for our universe.And all this occurs in the first three parts of this book – the first 9 chapters. After that it all becomes more challenging to follow but far less interesting. This is written by someone who has staked his professional career on this line of enquiry. So somewhat needless to say, it becomes pretty obsessive a promoting something that the jury are still pretty much out on. In fact String Theory and Dark Matter / Topology / Mirror Symmetry / the rifting of the fabric of Space-Time is all very interesting but it is all seen from the basis of a rather dodgy theory and it becomes somewhat tedious, particularly when the outcomes seem more and more tendentious and the chosen areas of research seem more and more sensational as if to grab the limelight alone. However, it is blue-sky thinking like this that produces major leaps in understanding! It just, for the layman like me, becomes harder and harder to follow, easier to lose track of what the bold Prof is banging on about. It begins to sound more and more like a teenager’s write up of a weekend of geekery away at the Hitchhikers Guide to the Universe Convention.The situation is neatly encapsulated at the start of chapter 12 when discussing the implications of a grand unified theory and is worth quoting. By the late 80s it appeared to the physicists that although String Theory came close to proving a unique picture of the universe it did not quite make the grade. There were two reasons for this. First..... physicists found that there were actually five different versions of String Theory.... they all shared many basic features – their vibrational patterns determine the possible mass and force charges, they require a total of 10 space-time dimensions, their curled up dimensions must be in one of the Calabi-Yau shapes.... This has been an embarrassment to String Theorists because although it is impressive to have a series of proposals for the final unified theory having five proposals takes significant wind from the sails of each.The second part may be summarised as there being many possible solutions to the equations derived from the theory each giving rise to a universe with diverse properties and apparently irrelevant to the world as we know it. It is the complexity of the theory itself which appears to give rise to all kinds of trouble. It may be right, but with so many options to choose from, if it isn't then you can always try one of the other variants... or better still try something entirely different. Thus perturbative theory, another further dimension, another version of String Theory, coupling constants all get thrown into the ring, but still there has yet to be achieved an experimentally verifiable outcome from String Theory. And by the end of chapter 12 it really does begin to feel that they are indeed making it all up as they go along and getting theory to fit observation rather than the other way.With the lack of experimental verification of theoretical outcomes, what does String Theory give us? Well, there is definite verification of the outcomes of other theories such as confirming Hawking’s work on Black Holes showing an increase in entropy and black hole radiation, but understanding why is well beyond even the way it is put here. And it should form the basis of analysis for singularities like black holes and the Big Bang where the effects of gravity and quantum mechanics have to be considered together. It may very well do but it does so in a language that no layman could possibly understand.This is a language FOR physicists, more properly for String Theory physicists. At times within the book it begins to sound like a religion in that to understand it you have to have both belief and faith. It seems all very touchie feelie, a bit like seeing String theorists as fiction writers. They’ve made some statements and identified some results which would appear to be consistent but they are lacking in the proof that what they say IS actually is. The insights emerging from the second String Theory revolution all appear to be insights into String Theory itself and not into the physical universe. There is this tautological element to String Theorists. To show evidence for 6/7 dimensional Calabi-Yau shapes they would likely reply that they must exist because String Theory exists.This is a bold book and a wild read but after chapter 9 it all gets a little fuzzy around the edges and really beyond the comprehension of the layman, which leads one to ask why it was written? Big things may come out of String Theory but until the confirmation of supersymmetry and superpartners we are left with a sense of this book providing a ‘this might be’ manual and be one of the first bricks down in the wall which we might in the future look back on and say that the groundwork had been laid. It is well worth the read at least up to chapter 9 and from thenm on its a kind of 'what-if' which may be a uesful reference in the future.

The elegant universe is a book about Super string theory. A theory that likely unifies the fundamental divide between general relativity and quantum mechanics. The importance of this is that it might be a theory of everything, something that Einstein searched for in his life. A final theory that would underlying all other theories and not require our allow a deeper explanatory base. Although this might be one of the most complex theories in science and the very forefront of physics, Brian Greene does a masterful job in explaining these big concepts and breaking it down bit by bit. I actually only picked this book up in the first place because I've heard him talk before on a podcast and also on Ted talks and he was so articulate and clear that I was confident I could understand one of his books. The upside of reading this book as well is that it's a joy to even try to wrap your head around these ideas. It's mind blowing and restructures tour understanding of reality. He starts with explaining what we know about the small. With quarks and the 3 families of fundamental particles (electrons, neutrino, muon and Tau particles) that in carrots combinations form everything in the universe. A bunch of questions arise from the sizes of these in comparison to each other and the combinations which a scientific explanation might be needed.Next Greene talks about the forces of nature. The 4 fundamental forces are the gravitational force, the electromagnetic force, the weak force and strong force (the 2 nuclear forces).What is string theory though. Well my crude way of explaining it is that if it was possible to examine these particles to a greater extent they would not be point like but rather of a one dimensional loop, an infinitely thin vibrating "rubber" band. That is why it's called string theory. Depending on the vibration of the loops, it will determine the structure of the particle. Although this will be a crucial part in explaining time, space and matter, it will not be the end of science but rather a key component to help it forward. String theory is so complex that it is still a work in progress and will continue to be for maybe decades in order for it to be mastered. So explaining space, time and the eye of the beholder. The paradox was basically that if light always travels at light speed, it is not possible to catch up to light of you were travelling at the speed of light. Therefore time and space are not concrete and can be different to the observer (I'm butchering this, I know). But this is basically what this chapter delves into. This discovery and mind bending theory goes against all basic "Newtonian" physics. There is no such thing as slower or stationary light. So if speed has to do with time and distance, and time and distance are not concrete, this makes the concept of the speed of light particularly hard to grasp. Taking that all into consideration, he gives the example of the document being signed on opposite sides of a moving train the moment each side sees the light being turned on in the very middle of the train. What the people observed inside the train being different to that outside the train as one side seemed to have reached the light before the other. This is especially visible again, at higher speeds. So could one potentially slow down time if one is in motion? The short answer is yes. He gives the real example of muons literally having a longer lifespan of they are in the hadron collider. That isn't too say that the fountain of youth is discovered as time also works as everything would also be going in slow motion. A amazing example is again with the astronauts floating by each other at almost light speed and then the other catching up to the one past. One would have gone 6 years and the other 60. Now the concept of time as a sort of 4th dimension. Even with a object being completely still in relation to us, it is still travelling through time at the same rate as everything else. Lastly a key part of special relativity is the importance of the speed of light with it making objects seem much smaller to a stationary observer in relation to the fast object and also how much mass is increased and finally that it's THE fastest speed possible. So much so that it is physically impossible to even be faster or in other words for information to be transferred from one shot to another. Which goes against Isaac Newton's laws of gravity affecting distant objects instantaneously. This is where Albert Einstein's theory of general relativity comes into play. Although Newton explains extensively the physics of gravity, he still does not explain entirely what gravity is so Einstein had to really get to the bottom of what gravity is but also how it fits into the laws of special relativity. Greene gives the example of the detonating bomb on a rocket and how essentially there is no difference between gravity and accelerated motion. Then with the example of the spinning amusement park ride, Greene outlines that gravity is the very distortion of time and space. A classic example of the basics of general relativity is the bowling ball on the trampoline representing a large object in space, like the sun for example. The mass of the object will distort space in all directions (as opposed to the flat trampoline) and thereby create what we know as gravity. It also distorts time as he explained with the astronauts example getting closer to the surface of the sun and his clock getting slower. This will happen to tiny degrees to the sun but to bigger proportions with a neutron star or even more so with a black hole. But does this go against what Newton predicted on having instantaneous change. Yes it does as the gravity doesn't change or affect anything instantaneously but rather at the speed of light in a short of ripple effect. Since these theories are so extreme and are extremely hard to test, they took a while to be considered valid but have since been proven to be undeniable and the basis of other theories. Now we can finally turn to quantum mechanics which he already makes clear that it will be infinitely harder to understand and that even many physicist have denied or not managed to comprehend the complex mathematics. I could not do justice of summarising the examples and logic behind the following few chapters but what I understood was that light travels in waves AND particles and so do matter particles as well. These are momentous discoveries that got Nobel prizes. The bulk of this part of the book actually focused on understanding energy waves and how they work. Einstein discovered that light travels in a short of steam of packets which were later named Photons. Ultimately the real mind boggling part of quantum mechanics is that it involves probability as opposed to constant certainty. When trying to explain the wave like nature of electrons, it was discovered that you could not recreate any experiment with exactness but only would have a probability. An example of this is the very location of the electron during any time is not replicable with certainty. This might seem insignificant but this is like as if God was playing dice and the future actually impossible to predict to a atomic level. The book turns to the physicist Richard Feynman and his sum over paths theory which I had to replay a thousand times to understand which electrons sort of "sniff out" all the different paths they can take at the same time before they do take the final one. If you find the average of all these paths, you will find the probability of the chosen path. And from what I understand that counts for big opponents as well somehow. Then another important physicist, Werner Heisenberg introduces the uncertainty principle which vastly distances itself from common sense or classical physics. The uncertainty principle which you cannot pinpoint the location or the speed of a particle because of the light (photons) would disrupt the movement of the individual electrons. More bizarre was the quantum tunnelling which is where using the information we know above, matter at a atomic level can go through other matter, like a ball travelling through a wall. The chances are very low but most importantly, it isn't zero. Absurd and chaotic frenzied nature of quantum mechanics is what doesn't make sense along side the smooth geometry of general relativity. String theory didn't take off with much enthusiasm my the science community and was originally created to explain only the strong force but when revisiting the theory because of its rich mathematics, it was discovered that string theory explains all of matter and also the 4 forces of the universe. Things get really interesting now with this theory changing the universe being point like but rather vibrating strings with impossible tight tension that creat everything. This makes the universe also have a definite smallest particle and cannot be further divided. The string is a one dimensional string. It is not made out of anything. The book then changes focus to the very laws of physics and of somewhere in the universe it could be different. The short answer according to Einstein is no but does that explain the "spin" on an electron although the electron is point like and shoes have a circumference to spin but at the same time by definition it being an electron, it never stops spinning. A new law of physics is then found which is essential for the mechanics of string theory with is called super symmetry. By now you're halfway done with the book and questioning how it can possibly get any more crazy. Well challenge accepted as we delve into other dimensions. Greene explains a separate theory of other dimensions which doesn't just line up with strong theory but is actually essential in order for it to be possible. The number of dimensions goes up to 11 including the dimension of time. The example of the garden hose dimension is a good way too grasp the idea of other tiny circular dimension, inside the very fabric of space. That then opens up the unknown possibility that there are other time dimensions. Completely bananas. The only way that these dimension apparently can be is in the form of a Calabi Yau shape. A intricate constantly moving geometrical shape that is the main subject basically the second half of this book. 5 different theories of calabi yau shapes and also a possibly uniting theory called M theory. How there are an infinite number of calabi Yau shapes and that there are intense mathematical processes to find matching ones. Later in the book Greene also brings up the concept of space itself tearing and how that relates to the Calabi Yau shape. In science fiction, a spacial tear is a worm hole which is sort of like a teleporter, but according to general relativity that could not happen. According to string theory and the Calabi Yau shape, a tear in space could be much more subtle and technically imperceptible an be happening somewhere right now which tiny adjustments. Naturally, what any laymen thinks about when hearing this is HOW on earth can any of this be tested. Well not much of it can be tested which causes a divide in philosophies in the physics community. Definitely lives up to the hype.But I stand by my summer of physics reading order:1. The Dancing Wu Li Masters, Gary Zukav2. A Brief History of Time, Stephen Hawking3. The Elegant Universe, Brian Greene--with an optional step 0 that should precede Zukav:0. Zen and the Art of the Motorcycle Maintenance, Robert Pirsig (but only read the first 2/3 or so)The reason for this order is that Zukav does the best job of explaining the major revelations in physics from Copernicus to Einstein on through to quantum mechanics. Pirsig's Zen is highly recommended before reading Zukav because Zukav takes a more philosophical view of physics; many of Zukav's abstract concepts come across much more clearly in Zen.Hawking is the least satisfying of the three, but goes the deepest into Einsteinian general relativity and the cosmic significance of gravity.With Zukav covering quantum mechanics and Hawking covering gravity, we are now ready for Greene whose superstring theory unites quantum mechanics with gravity.It's not an easy read, but it's not extraordinarily difficult either. I found it very enjoyable to read half a chapter or so in each sitting. He breaks up his discussion into easily digestable chunks, with multiple section headers further subdividing his chapters.He tells a compelling and exciting story, though the latter third of the book gets increasingly difficult. The problem is twofold. First, the physics moves further and further from our ability to visualize and innately understand--we can intuitively "get" a black hole, but we cannot intuitively understand a multidimensional cavity within a 6-dimensional clump of space-time. The second problem is that even if we could visualize a 6-D space, we can't see the relevance of it. Most of the core findings of superstring theory come out of these 6-D spaces. His discussion necessarily becomes one of mathematical proofs (though he does it without the math--he expertly talks us through the basic concepts with very little math lingo). The proofs in and of themselves are interesting, but can hardly compete with the cosmic significance of Hawking's black holes and wormholes. Greene puts in a heroic effort to convey the significance of each proof and does keep things interesting. But ultimately a big part of the book reads something like the following (with artistic liberties):"We know that there are 7 flimflams in the universe. This proof shows that the oogy-boogy inside the foobar has three whatsits. The math is extremely complex, but what we've been able to determine is that the three whatsits cause the foobar to generate 7 flimflams--exactly what experimental data confirms!"You get a little caught up in the excitement, but then immediately say, "uh, sounds cool, but so what?" The "So what?" does eventually come at the end and is worth arriving at, but you'll have to be patient and ride through all the revelations of whatsits and foobars and oogy-boogies that seem almost meaningless until you finally arrive at your destination.This is not a weakness of Brian Greene's writing. This is the inherent challenge of discussing superstring theory.In Wu Li, Zukav gave us a taste of quantum mechanics and its many, many mind-blowing oddities, but the realm of quantum mechanics is still just barely accessible to our minds and our imagination. No, we'll never see a quark with the naked eye, but we kind of get what it's all about. We can invoke a naive view of it as a building block for protons and neutrons, which, in turn, are the building blocks of atoms that we're all familiar with from high school chemistry.Quantum mechanics is the weird reality that underlies the world as we know it. But superstring theory is the even weirder reality that underlies quantum mechanics. It's just so far removed from our experience of reality.But weird as it is, it does seem to be getting us closer to understanding the fundamental nature of our universe--and perhaps even universes--and, more abstractly, it's just cool to marvel at how intelligent and clever human beings can be.It's worth reading, but if you're going to read it, do it right; follow the sequence outlined above.

I have no love for String Theory. There. I said it. String Theory has sucked all the fun out of physics! I could separate "The Elegant Universe: Superstrings, Hidden Dimensions, and the Quest for the Ultimate Theory" by Brian Greene into three parts. The first part of the book is impressive. The introduction and all the chapters up to page 100 or something are amazing. I devoured the content eagerly and giggled like a child who had just discovered their aunts and uncles and cousins had brought her dozens of birthday presents. I thought I'd finally found the answer to all of my questions about the Universe. I'd finally get all the sparkly, gravity-defying, mind-crushing presents! However, my burning enthusiasm for the book wore off as soon as supersymmetry was introduced. It felt like finding out that all the birthday presents were new, elegant socks and shirts that everyone thought you needed except you. And no matter how many people said they were awesome and perfect and just what you needed, deep down you knew you were never going to wear them and forever hate them. The second part of the book is all about Brian Greene trying to convince us why String Theory is so beautiful, but I haven't found a single evidence to support his claim. There are paragraphs upon paragraphs that tell you how it's just not possible to prove any of the theories, there are no ways to see the strings, there are no experiments that can prove we live in a multiverse, but you should just trust it because the theory is elegant and it's the answer to all your questions, you just can't see it. You need to believe it. String Theory will change the world. The number of hopes and beliefs appear as often as in the Bible. Actually, String theory is some sort of a religion for the scientists. You just believe in it, but no experiment can back it up. You write theories about it, you try to convince people that it is real, you write diagrams and equations, and draw simplified pictures of what you think is the answer, but you can't actually prove it. Of course, there's some truth in there, but it's skewed to fit the theory. People jump on your String Theory bandwagon because it's fresh and new and popular and scientists have been stuck in the dark since Einstein. Why wander alone when you can follow the crowd? That's how String Theory feels. Religion.Reading the third part of the book felt like dragging your nails across the blackboard or drinking stale water. Tastless and annoying. My fascination with photons (hell, yes, I love photons, they just like to kick electron's butt!) was replaced by vibrating loops of string. Hey, I can actually accept that. So, what? Particles are not actually point-like. They're small strings that vibrate. Oh, every particle is actually made of the same stuff, but they vibrate differently. Anyway, String Theory includes gravity (good for you!), but it still doesn't know anything else. String Theory can prove this and this and this, but it needs to include more dimensions for the equations to work. Hey, can't prove it, but it works in theory. Reading the last part of the book filled me with boredom, anger, frustration, apathy and indifference. All in that order. The text became increasingly difficult to follow. However, things got slightly better when M Theory was introduced but I had to re-read some chapters of Hawking's "The Grand Design" to understand what Greene was trying to tell me. Once I managed to comprehend the idea behind the Multiverse, I finished the rest of the book quickly. Multiverse is such an interesting concept, I only wish it could give us a sign of existence. I'll definitely read “The Trouble with Physics: The Rise of String Theory, the Fall of a Science and What Comes Next" by Lee Smolin to get a better understanding of the problem of String Theory.After finishing the book I was left with the impression that string theory physicists have been looking at a grain of sand for too long they've forgotten to see the bigger picture-that they are in a vast, empty cosmic desert.

It's been quite some time since I've read a popular physics book, so I enjoyed the first part of The Elegant Universe, which is a good introduction to the core concepts of physics including Relativity and Quantum Mechanics. This was a good refresher and helped to solidify these concepts in my mind, as well as reminding me of a few things I'd forgotten over the years.I enjoyed the rest of the book less, for a number of reasons. Firstly, the science around String and M theories is much less settled, and is more speculative. As a lay person with only very light exposure to developments in the field, it is impossible for me to determine what is accepted science and what is hopeful conjecture. Greene obviously has a dog in this fight, and so I'm not entirely comfortable with taking his opinion as fact. Also, this book was written in 1999, and surely the field has developed significantly since then. So I took the the whole section around String and M theory with a massive grain of salt. And honestly the approach to explanation in this section is not as good as early in the book - he focuses more on his personal involvement and the work of his colleagues, rather than on exploring the underlying concepts in detail. On an aesthetic level, there is something about these theories - actually much of the standard model, especially supersymmetry - that I find unconvincing, and although I accept that the scientific nature of reality does not hinge on aesthetics, it's difficult for me to ignore this personal bias. The theoretical components seem so piecemeal and inelegant, like the model has been squeezed and distorted in order to fit the experimental data, and the result is just a mess, with good predictive but little real explanatory power. It may work mathematically, but it seems strange for such a generally elegant and orderly universe to be based on such arbitrary principles. A good comparison would be with orbital epicycles, which were adequate predictive models, but are messy and inelegant and were eventually replaced by Newton's simpler and far more elegant solution to the problem - Newton's paradigmatic innovation being to consider elliptical orbits rather than circular ones. It seems as though we are at a similar stage with the current state of the Standard Model - inventing patches and workarounds to fit with the experimental data, and waiting for a paradigm shift for the pieces to fall into place. String and M theory go some way toward trying to address this, but even if they were experimentally validated, the model is still not satisfying and it's difficult not to imagine that there is still some deeper understanding that is eluding us.
